title: 106_s3254
content:
The Act may be cited as the "East Timor Transition to Independence Act of 2000". The East Timorese people voted for independence from Indonesia in 1999, leading to a violent campaign by anti-independence militias supported by the Indonesian military. This resulted in the displacement of 500,000 people, destruction of infrastructure, and collapse of government services. The International Force for East Timor restored order, followed by the United Nations Transitional Administration for East Timor guiding the establishment of a new democratic government. East Timor is anticipated to become an independent nation by late 2001. It is one of the poorest places in Asia with high poverty rates, low literacy levels, high unemployment, and a low life expectancy. Development assistance of $300 million over the next three years is estimated to be needed to meet basic development needs. Sense of Congress supports East Timor's independence. The United States should support East Timor's transition to independence, democracy, economic recovery, and security. It should also establish diplomatic relations, open a diplomatic mission, and support justice efforts related to past atrocities in East Timor. The United States should support East Timor's transition to independence, democracy, economic recovery, and security. This includes providing technical assistance for the development of East Timor's judicial system and potentially establishing an international tribunal. Additionally, supporting observer status for an official delegation from East Timor in the Asia Pacific Economic Co-operation (APEC) group. The United States should provide bilateral assistance to East Timor for its transition to independence, democracy, economic recovery, and security. This may include technical support for the judicial system and potentially establishing an international tribunal. Additionally, supporting observer status for an official delegation from East Timor in the Asia Pacific Economic Co-operation (APEC) group. The President, through the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, is authorized to support civil society, independent media, job creation, economic development, reconciliation, repatriation of refugees, and political party development in East Timor. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. Authorized appropriations of $25,000,000 for each fiscal year 2001-2003 to support various initiatives in East Timor, with funds remaining available until expended. The President shall instruct the US executive director at international financial institutions to support economic and democratic development in East Timor. The Peace Corps is authorized to provide training and assistance in East Timor, with $2,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year 2001-2003. SEC. 7. TRADE AND INVESTMENT ASSISTANCE. The President should negotiate with UNTAET, National Council of East Timor, and East Timor government to expand US investment in East Timor through OPIC agreements. The Trade and Development Agency is authorized to carry out projects in East Timor with an appropriation of $1 million for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2003. The Export-Import Bank of the United States is authorized to expand its activities in connection with exports to East Timor for fiscal years 2001, 2002, and 2003. Amounts appropriated for this purpose are authorized to remain available until expended. SEC. 8. GENERALIZED SYSTEM OF PREFERENCES.

Sense of Congress: President should encourage UNTAET and National Council of East Timor to seek duty-free treatment under Trade Act of 1974.
Technical Assistance: US Trade Representative and Customs Service authorized to provide assistance for East Timor's eligibility for duty-free treatment.

SEC. 9. BILATERAL INVESTMENT TREATY.

Sense of Congress: President should enter into bilateral investment treaty with UNTAET and National Council of East Timor for stable legal framework for US investment in East Timor. SEC. 10. SCHOLARSHIPS FOR EAST TIMORESE STUDENTS.

The Secretary of State is authorized to establish an East Timorese scholarship program for students interested in studying in the US. $1,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2002 and 2003 for this purpose.

SEC. 11. PLAN FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF DIPLOMATIC FACILITIES IN EAST TIMOR. The Secretary of State is tasked with developing a detailed plan for establishing a US diplomatic mission in East Timor, including opening a fully functioning mission upon East Timor's independence. A report with a timetable for opening a facility in Dili must be submitted to relevant committees within three months of the enactment of this Act. The Secretary of State must provide reports every six months on the implementation of the plan for establishing a US diplomatic mission in East Timor, including details on costs, security requirements, and any revisions made to the plan. Reports can be submitted in classified or unclassified form. SEC. 12. SECURITY ASSISTANCE FOR EAST TIMOR. Authorization for the President to transfer defense articles and provide military education and training to East Timor, contingent upon certification of East Timor's independent armed forces and alignment with US national security interests and human rights promotion. The President will conduct a study to determine the extent to which East Timor's security needs can be met through the transfer of excess defense articles and international military education and training assistance. A report on the findings of the study must be submitted to relevant committees within 1 month of the enactment of the Act. Representatives will present the study findings conducted to address East Timor's security needs through defense articles transfer and military education assistance. The Broadcasting Board of Governors is authorized to increase the use of radio broadcasting to East Timor to ensure reliable news. Additionally, a reporting requirement is in place. The Secretary of State, along with other government agencies, is required to submit reports every six months on East Timor's political and economic situation, including elections and refugee reintegration. The reports on East Timor must include a 3-year plan for US foreign assistance, details of expenditure, activities by international banks, and an assessment of trade and investment relations. The report on East Timor should include details on US-East Timor cultural exchanges, education, scientific collaborations, Peace Corps activities, and a study on local agriculture with recommendations for technical assistance from the United States.
